Yes, there are initiatives aimed at increasing the production of organic hemp. One such initiative is the Organic Hemp Certification Program, which was developed by the Organic Trade Association (OTA) and the Hemp Industries Association (HIA) to encourage the cultivation of organic hemp in the United States. This program provides guidelines for best practices in growing organic hemp, as well as a certification process for farmers who meet these standards. 

In addition, there are several organizations and companies that are working to increase the availability of organic hemp. For example, Patagonia, a clothing company that uses hemp in some of its products, has partnered with a group of farmers in Kentucky to develop a pilot program for growing organic hemp. The company is also providing support to help these farmers meet the rigorous organic certification standards. 

Finally, consumers can also play a role in increasing the availability of organic hemp by supporting companies that use organic hemp in their products and advocating for greater investment in organic agriculture. As demand for organic hemp grows, more farmers and manufacturers may be incentivized to adopt sustainable practices and invest in organic production.
